Also, note that the explanation given about pressure equalization pulling a vacuum to draw new air into the chamber after projectile exit roughly depicts the continuous operation function occurring within a 2-stroke engine!

This is impressive. What is important to note is how the energy release during combustion can be modified to produce different time-relative curves of acceleration against the projectile. Note that although total energy release will remain roughly the same during the event of the potato traveling the barrel length, it's acceleration was greatly different during both scenarios. The second event utilizing chamber-central initiation saw a pressure rise roughly twice that of chamber-rear initiation. What would be interesting to know would be the velocity outcome of the potato upon barrel exit! With chamber-central initiation, it appeared to have a greater ending velocity due to greater impulse occurring sooner. What was the velocity difference between the shots? Edit: It appears I was wrong, my eyes were focused on the illuminated flame front, not the potato. Now that I have rewatched the video a few times, it appears the potato left slower using chamber-central ignition. Now I really want to know the velocity outcomes!

My hypothesis is that when you fire it from the end there is more air that can be compressed against the potato before it overcomes the friction holding it in place allowing for much higher velocity as more energy can be put into the system. If you light it in the middle, if you watch closely the potato moves the second the flames touch the sides of the tube because there is much less air to be compressed against the potato as half of that air is just being compressed against the end cap rather than the potato which is also going to add unwanted stress to the system as its most likely doubling the force being applied on the threads holding on the end cap. The way im thinking of this cannon is the flames act as a plunger compressing the air fuel mixture that cannot combust due to being too rich or too lean so the more of that mixture you can put between the plunger and what it is pressing against the more compression and force you will get acted on the potato so if you move the plunger forward there is less to compress therfore less force is imparted on the potato. It you break it down into known concepts its much easier to understand what is going on. Its not the flames that are launching the potato its the pressure increase those flames produce on the excess air that propels the object forward. I wonder what would happen if all of the air was used up at the same time instead of being a rolling flame would it create a vacuum, would nothing happen to the potato, or would the same thing happen as if it were running lean like it is now.

An observation: Your barrel is slightly too long. You can see this by observing the closeup of the combustion chamber when firing from the base end igniter. Observe the gas flow at the barrel end of the combustion chamber and the base of the barrel. You will observe teh flame front moving through the chamber and into the barrel but then reversing just before rapidly flowing out the barrel.

The reversal is most likely due to the collapse of the combustion impulse (perhaps due to oxygen depletion) which is then followed by the projectile leaving the barrel and opening the barrel and chamber to atmospheric pressure which is substantially lower. The pressure differential then causes relatively higher pressure gases in the device to exit rapidly until pressure equalization.

@SmarterEveryDay: Just a technical FYI.

There are two types of combustion: deflagration and detonation (explosion). If your flame front is travelling subsonically, then you have deflagration. If supersonic, then detonation. You shot your video at 20k fps, but I don't know the playback fps nor the length of the tube, so I must leave it to you to do the calculation.

I suspect that what you observed was a subsonic wavefront. Subsonic wavefronts are found in internal combustion engines and firearms. I know that there are firearms that shoot supersonic bullets, but the bullet is accelerated down the barrel by pressure, not by the flame's wavefront. You can see that in the transparent potato gun. The potato starts to move before the flame's wavefront hits it.

If it had been an explosion, (supersonic wavefront), you would have had thick pieces of plastic embedded in your torso. So, thankfully for you, you were not actually holding an explosion.

All that said, it is a very cool video! Thanks for making it!

A great start. You could use this footage or new similar footage to determine the best way to fire your potato gun. The key is measurement. The velocity of the projectile at the moment of departure from the muzzle determines the distance and force of the shot. If you do all this again and focus on the potato accelerating through the barrel and time-stamp initial motion and departure from the barrel, you can determine length of time in the barrel. To be even more precise, mark the duration between the potato 1 foot from the end of the barrel and the potato exiting. From what I could tell, the center ignition got the potato moving sooner, but much more slowly.

hi In your video at 4:40 you have mentioned that as the flame front progresses from the middle of the chamber a part of the fuel air mixture is not burnt at the closed end of the chamber, after the potato has left the barrel, fresh oxygen from atmosphere is sucked back in and the remaining gases are burnt down. But video after the 5:10 is telling a completely different story, your Flame cells indicate that the flame is in lean side not in rich side, your claim is possible only when the fuel air mixture is in the lean side (Jelly jar combustor). In my observation I find that as the flame front approaches the closed end of the chamber the in front of it is compressed as the burnt gases try to expand, as the pressure builds up the flame speed decreases ans it apears to slow down not quench. As the projectile starts to move in the barrel that leads to volume expansion which in turn allows the compressed air at the end to push flame front. when the pressure in the barrel drops sufficiently low enough the flame front reignites the remaining gas mixture in the chamber. However we can still see that there is an oscillation of gases in the chamber and the barrel once the potato has exited, this is purely due to the acoustics of the duct (pressure wave).

Did I miss the word "propagation"?
The ignition of any firearm should begin at the rear of the fuel/charge creating a burning and continually pressure wave that propagates forward accelerating the projectile to the maximum possible velocity.
By igniting it in the center half of the pressure wave is headed the wrong way, at least initally until it hits the rear cap (with arguably much more force than it would if ignition began at the cap).
Also, by drilling two holes in the center of the chamber like that you've compromised its burst limits.. I'd throw that mess away before it rips your stomach open.
With a cap failure it simply blows out the back, harmlessly, as it should. (which is why the flint igniter is a bad idea too with a hand/fingers in the way)

Starting from the middle leaves unburned fuel in the back. Starting from the back looks like it shoots unburned fuel out the end of the barrel because it's not long enough. Do you think having one ignition happen at the top and bottom of the combustion chamber would make the system more efficient?

This is why Alphas and almost every small aircraft engine (Lycoming, Rotax, etc.) have sort of a twin spark or dual magnet ignition. You get the job done more effective, if your're able to burn all the pushing gasses, before the piston reaches lower dead center or the potato reaches the muzzle. It is also very silly to have a .357 or .44 magnum revolver with a 2" barrel. The powder grains have barely burnt through, before the bullet has left the barrel. The ideal combustion chamber in an engine or a potato gun or a cartridge is spherical (most stable and least surface area and the ignition takes place in multiple spots at the same time. A cylinder in an engine can't be spherical, because of the given piston bore, but your potato gun's could! The ideal lambda value in your potato gun is around one! 3:11 Being a guy who works with fuel/air combustion properties for a living, I can say that the amount of fuel you are using for the volume of your chamber is excessive. A spray of about 2 seconds should be sufficient to create a more powerful combustion. If you flood the chamber with too much fuel it reduces the amount of oxygen that can also be present which lowers the power of the explosion significantly. Try with a 1 second spray. Then 2 second spray, then keep increasing it until you get a power loss. That's the best way to "tune" it, similar to tuning a car's engine fuel delivery system on a dyno, except on the dyno you start overly rich, then lean it out gradually with each successive dyno run. Also, try an aerosol can of engine starter fluid instead of hair spray, or put gasoline or alcohol or E85 into an aerosol can or other spray gun to atomize it and test which burns slower/faster and determine which is best for your chamber/barrel length...not that I've tried any of this yet ;)

So I've been looking at a couple potato gun videos on YouTube. There is something I expected to see in at least one or two of them, but I never did. Quick disclaimer: I've never made a potato gun myself. Maybe my understanding is wrong, but I always thought that the correct way to load/shoot a potato gun was to spray the combustion fuel into the chamber before plunging the potato. The potato goes on the end of the barrel creating a seal, the combustion chamber is opened and the fuel sprayed in, finally, the potato is plunged down the end of the barrel before firing. This last step allows the fuel-air mixture to become compressed as the potato, loaded earlier, created a seal and then was pushed down the barrel like the piston of an air-compressor but with an exceptionally long stroke length. The final result should be a greater explosion. Could you possibly answer this question in one of your videos, or even do an experiment in which this method is tested?

I'm a few years late with the comment ... but have you ever tried filming a hydrogen/O2 mixture burning?  A few years back I was experimenting with electrolysis of water and I'd swear the gas in my tubes would implode (the O2 and H gas combining back to water vapour)  heating the vapour product producing steam that would explode.  I had maybe a 10 foot 1/2" clear tubing bubbling out of a pool of water.  The water was sort of a poor man's check valve.  When I would purposely ignite it inside my reactor, you could see it suck the water up the tubes first before pushing it all out. Because it's an unstable gas ( H gas in perfect proportion with O2 gas , I experimented at only 15 psi and with only a very small amount I was producing on the spot with 12V 15-30Amps.  I was really neat experimenting with this gas mixture in a ballon or bag - very unique explosion. Eventually, I was able to produce a consistent cutting flame (my objective was an alternative to my car's hydrocarbon fuels)  ... then winter came, my water froze, and I moved on with the distraction of living a full life  ... Wondering?  Have you considered this yet?

I have a couple of experiences with combustion, first is way back when, Champion spark plugs would travel around putting on demos, how plug heat ranges work, cross fire and the difference in timing required for different octanes of gas, the guy used a clean tube, would place a few drops of gas in one end, wait till it vaporized and then lit it with a lighter, low octane the flame would travel at a steady speed up the tube, high octane would travel about half way and then go off like a gun, really cool, my other experience is with testing gas appliances, fireplaces to be exact, all gas appliances must pass explosion testing, that where you have to put the maximum air/fuel into the appliance to get the maximum explosion and the appliance still has to function normal, that's a fun day in the lab, everyone hides behind a glass screen when it gets lit, sometimes it fails and parts fly...lol, to get the maximum explosion we just time how long the gas enters the unit and light it, vent the unit well and then add more gas or less, great fun

I think there is something you're missing. When combustion begins in the middle of the chamber, the expanding gas has momentum in both directions. The wave pushing backward does work (compresses) on the unburnt gases first. The energy is not wasted, but it has to reflect off the back and come forward again producing a late wave which does not contribute to the work on the potato. You might think that the burning gases in the middle as a unit would propel itself toward the front from the energy released toward the back but this is not the case. Therefore only the gases expanding forward contribute to pushing the potato out of the barrel.

I just thought, if you insert a one-way valve into the back of the burning chamber, the vacuum after the combustion could suck the air in from the back and direct the force of the second expansion better. This could maybe increase the efficiency of the whole system...(?)

I have a bit of a solution/theory about the delayed burning of the fuel. When I made my first potato gun, I couldn't get the electronic ignition system to work, so instead, I drilled a 1/4 hole in the middle of the endcap, and I'd use a long barbecue lighter to ignite it. You would think that it wouldn't be as effective, since it provides an outlet for flame to escape, however, it actually shot further than a regular electronically ignited launcher that I built a couple weeks after. I'm guessing it's because the hole provided a vent for some air to get in, allowing for better burn rate on the hairspray. Just a theory I came up with though. Could also be because my potato gun building skills are sub-par though.

Great Video!  Like Dustin said, "There's multiple PhD dissertations in a potato gun."  Built one for my high schooler to teach concept of stoichiometry and soon learned that I was also teaching pressure-volume-temperature lessons. We started with hair spray, but that didn't really teach the concepts, so we moved to propane as fuel.  We built a "metering device" to deliver just the right amount of propane (4% in air, or 20% in pure oxygen) for our 4" x 48" PVC combustion chamber.  We also added a brushless 12v computer fan to mix the propane/air mixture prior to ignition.  To standardize our potato weights and shape, we cut them all 5" long and "cored" them into our 1-1/2" x 60" PVC barrel.  Our original design used only one BBQ ignitor spark centered in the combustion chamber.  Inclined at 45 degrees, our potatoes averaged 138 yards.  Hypothesizing more sparks, means more burning wave fronts, faster pressure build up, and further distance, we increased the number to 2, 3, 4, 5 sparks evenly spaced w/in our 48" long combustion chamber.  We averaged 157 yards w/ 2 spark points, 174 yards with 3 sparks, 180 yards with 4 sparks, and no further improvement with 5 sparks.  Finally we purchased a rifled 1-1/2" x 60" PVC barrel online.  That added nearly 100 yards to our distances!!!  We averaged 266 yards with 4% propane/air, 4 spark points, and rifled barrel.  Needless to say: Hearing protection is a must!  Too scared to try 20% propane + pure oxygen in a PVC combustion chamber.

Your fuel type, compression ratio, fuel metering system and method of carburetion all affect the end result, as does the fact that the potato can leave the barrel before the fuel is fully consumed.

I would suggest you take the steps of
1, Use something like ether which is 100% high volatility fuel [I only say that because it looks like you used hair spray which has water and perfumes in it which will rob you of power and reduce mixing] or propane,
2, Inject the fuel into the chamber through a back-flash protected port instead of just spraying it in from the end, which pushes out most of your air,
3, Put the spud ONLY into the tip of the barrel before injecting the fuel so you can use it, along with all of the trapped air and trapped fuel to greatly increase the pressure ratio and usable air,
4, Give the device about 20 seconds to mix really well before igniting
5, Stand back with a really long wire when you fire it, because it just might explode on you!

G'day Destin, Grace and peace to you and your family.  Can i offer a tweek to your loading procedure? try charging the canon without the potato in the end... (creates a venturi) there is no need to count how long your spraying for... just spray till you can see a mist at the muzzle.... have someone cap the end with the potato, and fit your breach cap, then drive the potato down into the closed system ( this compresses the gas mix and maximizes the amount of fuel onboard ). Secondly, if you want a "harder" projectile, fill a short length of pipe (same as your barrel) with potatoes or oranges, then let them thaw for long enough to thaw the outer 1/4"... soft to seal, frozen to penetrate... Please be aware, there is a MASSIVE difference in performance between a fuel rich mix and the leaner one as i have suggested... God Bless and stay safe!

Like turbo-compressors, if you pump a pressurized mix of air and fuel, there will be more oxygen to burn, resulting in a powerful combustion. But, since an higher pressure would push the potato along the barrel, maybe it would be better if you just put a low-pressure valve in the backside of the combustion chamber. You can try with a sphygmomanometer valve (that thing used to measure blood pressure), which is located in the hand-pump. It works at low pressures. Obviuosly it'll not work while the combustion is spreading, but near the end the combustion should suck the needed air from the valve instead of the barrel, resulting in a better after-combustion thrust. Not sure about this tho, since the barrel have a lower friction then any type of valve. Just try :3

So I'm thinking it might look better with the end ignite because some of the fuel is getting pushed down the barrel, so even though it's not burning either, the entire combustion chamber is filled with flame. With the center light case where the fuel is still in there to burn on the rebound, you can see it clearly, but from the end ignite, the fuel gets shot out with the potato and either doesn't burn or burns outside the muzzle. You can see the center ignite fills the ignition chamber (as much as it does) in about 40ms vs about 70ms, too, so even if it does burn less well, it reaches max pressure sooner, and applies high pressure for a greater distance of potato travel, so it might impart more energy to the potato. Time to measure the outcome: potato distance (probably want some sort of "tracer potato" for that), or a momentum test (shoot it into a bucket with a relatively small hole so all the chunks stay in, with the bucket hanging from some kind of swing, measure how high the swing reaches when impacted by the potato)

You didn't say which method is more efficient (gives you more power). While sparking in the middle makes the gasses at one end hover until you get more fresh air inside, sparking in the end makes you have un-burnt gasses escape through the business end of the cannon.
My money is still on sparking at the middle, (and using a little bit less spray, to have a more balanced mixture), simply because if you spark in the middle the gasses burn in 2 directions as opposed to one, so the expansion is faster. The cannon seems to have a bit more "kick" when firing this way.

I'm reminded of a story about students set a task by their lecturer. How long will it take for a 3 kg piece of meat to reach a temperature of 120 C in the centre if placed in an environment of 250 C..

Student 1 theorizes that as meat is over 90% water, the rate of heat transfer would be about the same, and worked calculations accordingly.

Student 2 went and bought a 3 kg piece of meat and a probe thermometer, placed the meat in an oven at 250 C and probed the meat every 10 minutes until the internal temperature was 100, then every 2 minutes thereafter.

Student 3 rang his mother and asked her how long to cook a 3 kg piece of meat at 250 C to get the centre well cooked.

Which was the best method? Years of cooking experience versus a single experiment versus a theoretical calculation?

It seems to me that years of experience are the winner here.

What you have there is very similar to the test apparatus we used to use to determine the explosion ranges for coal dust. A vertical tube about 3 inch diameter and a pair of electrodes ( for the spark ) at midpoint. A measured quantity of coal dust of known granular range at the bottom. hey bud. the rear combustion is more efficient and creates more pressure. the centre combustion a faster combustion but as you said has pockets of air forming at the back. or pockets of unburned fuel. an easy solution and a method to create an even more efficient combustion and total combustion in the quickest time would be to use both the rear and centre igniters. if you follow what I am saying then you will notice that as the center igniter combusts the fuel it forces gas both forwards and backwards, if you then also use the rear igniter the combustion of the back will create recoil pressure where it meets with the combustion from the centre igniter. thus building double the pressure and causing a much faster and more powerful potato launch.

I made one of these with a friend for a 6th grade science project in 1997. We told our parents we were making a potato gun and they were like "Aww, okay sweetie". Me and my buddy used our lunch money that we had saved up and ended up using two screws through a 3" chamber with a piezoelectric BBQ ignitor and cap mounted striker ignition on two different models and tested them with three different brands of hairspray at the same inclination to figure out what was the best combustion method and fuel and measured how far the projectiles traveled before impact. We both got suspended and could not compete because our presentation used the word "gun" lol.

Btw, piezoelectric middle-mounted wood screws with aquanet hairspray worked best.

When I was a kid I used to explode empty plastic bleach bottles by filling them with oxygen + acetylene from a torch. In order to get the perforce proportions of oxygen to acetylene I did the following.

1. Fill the bleach bottle full with water.
2. Fill a washtub with 4 inches of water.
3. Light the torch and adjust the flame for a perfect burn.
4. Press the torch tip to the pavement to extinguish the flame.
5. Invert the bleach bottle in the washtub so that it was still full of water.
6. Put the torch into the mouth of the bleach bottle so that the oxygen + acetylene mixture displaced the water in the bottle.
6. When the bottle is empty of water and full of the perfect combustion mix, cap the bottle.

This left me with a one gallon plastic bottle exactly full of combustible gas. Not acetylene + air but acetylene + oxygen.
So I'd love to see you do something similar with your transparent potato gun and show is the slo-mo of that combustion event. But I'm not sure you should be holding the gun when you light it off. I used thin plastic bottles so that they did not generate any dangerously sharp shrapnel. :) Even as a kid doing stupid things, I was careful about safety.

2 things.  1) Chamfer the end of the barrel slightly so that it compresses the potato as you load it (use the barrel to cut the potato.  2) Use less fuel.  If you hit a slightly rich stoichiometry your deflagration rate will increase.  When you load the potato, just insert it into the end.  Then add fuel.  After capping, push the potato down which will compress the gas and air mixture making the deflagration rate even faster.  Ignite it quickly as the pressure will have a tendency to escape.  This of course, assumes you have a well sealed combustion chamber.  You'll be surprised at the difference it makes.

To me it looks like your original hypothesis is correct, assuming your charge gas is similar in both test cases. From the point of ignition to the projectile leaving the barrel takes about 13 seconds of high speed footage when ignited from the end, and about 10 when ignited in the centre. I'm not going to calculate the actual speed, but it is probable that the higher average speed through the barrel results in the higher exit speed.
The ideal shape for a combustion chamber is a sphere when it is ignited from the centre. This is because the flame front can propagate equally in every direction and so burn the whole charge gas as rapidly as possible. When you ignite from one end you limit how rapidly the flame front can propagate through the mixture for a given volume. One exception to this is that if you have a sufficiently long combustion chamber with sufficiently reactive mixture you could potentially accelerate the flame front to reinforce with the pressure wave and therefore detonate. At that point you wouldn't want to be anywhere near that plastic tube.

+SmarterEveryDay I just wanted to point out that if you refill the chamber with oxygen between rounds, it will fire more efficiently. Your results might be the same, but from what I've found it is hard to refill the chamber completely. Even blowing a fan through it has a hard time clearing it out for some reason.

The best way I have found to clear the chamber from the fumes of the previous round is to fill it with water, then pour it out. This is tedious, but if you do some testing, I think you will see that alternative methods don't provide as clean of a result. If you do find a good alternative method, let me know.

Destin,

In case you didn:t already know, it speeds up because of Burnoulli's Principle. Pressure and velocity are inversely proportional. Pressure decreases as velocity increases, and pressure increases as velocity decreases. That is how thrust happens. convergent ducts increase velocity and thrust while divergent ducts increase pressure. The cumbustion chamber was basically your divergent duct. And that is how it propels the potato. Aviation and your potato canon are based entirely off of Burnoulli's Principle.

I was thinking of this in two ways:
End: The Explosion has an unimpeded path of expansion resulting in some force. When the explosion contacts the potato, however, the force pushing back from the potato is too great for the expansion to continue, so it loses energy and compresses the other end of the combustion chamber, before the compressed force overcomes the potato thus propelling it.

Middle: The explosion has two directions of travel, the oxygen is burned quicker, however, the equal expansion means that there is no delay in the expansion whenever the explosive force contacts the potato.

There is a tradeoff, I'm not sure what the measureable difference is though.

I would recommend compressing the oxygen down into the tube, enough to make 4-16psi of pressure, then adding a 8-24:1 fuel mixture via a filler valve. You could use whatever gas, but I'd think a propane filler valve and propane would be the easiest.

Alternatively, you could spray the mix in at the end of the barrel then load the potato...

Hmm, I can't agree with your conclusions about which ignition point is better. It seems obvious to me that there is still a lot of combustion happening after the potato leaves the barrel, in both cases, meaning there is a lot of energy released after it has any chance of propelling the potato, and it's not obvious at all that the center-ignition case is worse because of oxygen missing at the spots you mentioned.

I would guess that center-ignition is probably better because it burns more fuel (because it has twice the "surface" where combustion is happening) while the potato is still in the gun, therefore creating more pressure and shooting the potato faster and further. Your video seems to confirm this - I tried timing (using the millisecond timer you have there in the corner) the time it takes from the point where I can see the potato barely moving, to where it has just left the barrel, and I got ~47ms for the end-of-chamber-ignition shot, and ~42ms for the center-of-chamber-ignition shot - implying that the second potato received more acceleration and left the barrel at a higher speed, with about a 10% improvement. But, of course, this is just one sample each, the variation could be caused by the amount of fuel you used, the mass of the potatoes, the friction characteristics of each of the specific potatoes, etc, not to mention my inability to see when exactly each of the potatoes started moving and when they left the barrel.

I'd say, if you want proper results for this experiment, to determine which type of ignition is better for the specific gun & fuel combo, you're just going to have to fire a lot of shots using each method in a controlled environment - enough to have valid statistics to smooth out any possible variation in potato mass, friction & amount of fuel inconsistencies; try to use the same amount of fuel every time, try to use a fair & random sampling of potatoes for each of the methods, and either measure the speed of the potato after leaving the barrel, or the distance it travels (in which case, probably do it in a warehouse or something, to eliminate wind conditions). Now, those are results I would trust. Also, my fingers are still crossed for center-ignition, but you can prove me wrong by actually doing the experiment.

Yours truly,
Fellow concerned potato gun enthusiast

You just had your theory backwards is all.
What you showed was the difference in a "normal" engine and a " hemi".
When you ignited from the back center of the tube is when you got the best combustion. Just think of it as a cylinder in an engine and you're pushing a piston instead of a potato.
In most engines the spark plug is to the side of the cylinder, the top of the chamber is flattened and the explosion has to travel across before it pushes down. In a "hemi" (hemispherical head) the spark plug is top center and the space in the head where the valves and spark plug are is curved as a half sphere (hemishere). This gives better more even combustion and the force is traveling in the intended direction the entire time thus more horsepower. BTW...Dodge isn't the only one who uses hemi engines, just the only one advertising it.

but did we really learn all we could from this? what were the actual projectile velocities from rear ignition vs center ignition? that would give us the true answer.
you're saying that the fuel is burned more thoroughly with the rear ignition, but i feel like you're only basing that on the fact that you get to see the re-ignition with the center method. what i think you may not have thought about is, the same thing may be happening with the rear ignition method, but since all the unburnt gas is expelled, there's no way to tell how much was initially burned just from looking at it. so really, the only way to know which method burns the most gas (before the projectile is expelled) is by measuring the muzzle velocity. (which can be done mythbusters style, with a simple ruler placed behind the projectile; then count the video frames, etc.)
and last, when you measure the MV, maybe you should try both methods separately, and then try them both simultaneously. i would be willing to bet that you'll burn a lot more fuel before the projectile leaves the barrel with both methods together, and thereby impart much more energy to it.

So, Destin, I noticed you're looking at the efficiency of your cannon from a strictly chemistry standpoint. Your goal is to burn as much fuel as possible. However, you've somewhat ignored the physics of it. You have a very long barrel, meaning more time to accelerate the potato. It may be very possible that igniting the fuel from the middle of the chamber would be best because you'd get a stronger reaction through the duration where the potato accelerates through the barrel. It is, however, possible that the opposite is still true and that ignition at the base is best. Especially considering prior knowledge that combustion chambers such as guns and pistons in a car are ignited from the bottom, implying that it may be the most efficient method. Either way, you should analyze the videos you took and see which gives the best acceleration and draw conclusions from that.

During WW2 the Germans built a multi-chambered artillery cannon called "Vergeltungswaffe 3" which could range ca.290km and shell London over the English Channel.
The combustion chamber was ignited at the rear but as the gasses expanded down the chamber a second charge would be detonated. As it expanded again to a third point, a third charge would be detonated and so on until the 150mm shell would emerge at the end of the 150m barrel traveling ca.1524m/s.

Actually, both firing situations are producing the same amount of unburnt fuel.  When firing from the end of the tube, the unburnt fuel is at the potato and is the reason the ignition is louder (50% more fuel is igniting in the smaller tube and in the open atmosphere.)  Firing in the middle gives 2x flame front surface area and thus 2x quicker pressure buildup giving more time for fuel to ignite before the potato leaves the tube.  Firing in the middle also reduces emissions since 50% less fuel is escaping unburnt.

Is possible for you to run some sort of colorimetric analysis of the video feed? I have a "Colortune" combustion analyser kit for small engines. Its basically a custom spark plug that has a quartz window with a conductive electrode running through the middle to provide the spark gap just like a normal plug has, to ignite the air fuel mixture at the appointed time, during normal engine operation (2 or 4 stroke versions). It has an adjustable angle mirror that reflects the imaged colors from the detonation event to an angle one can easily observe (best viewing is done in a darkened environment). It came with a "color-tune" visual chart so one can identify the related combustion parameters associated with various carburetor adjustments. I could not identify by color variations within the flame front or within the main cylinder burn, a tint of the color blue. Hey Dustin,
Myself and a few fellow engineers decided to test your different ignition locations on our potato gun. In short, we found that having the ignition point at the rear of the combustion chamber yielded a weaker shot, meaning the potato did not travel as far as having the ignition point up closer to the front of the potato gun. We were hoping you could do a comparison video test to see which locations yielded a higher muzzle velocity, and distance the potato traveled and why this is happening.

Thank you for considering!

I think the spark in the middle might not be as bad as it might seem. Yes, there's unburnt fuel at the base, but it's not about burning all the fuel efficiently, it's about creating the biggest pressure differential before the potato leaves the tube. So the middle spark may be able to react more fuel at a quicker rate, as opposed to the other method, which yes, could burn more fuel, but does some of the fuel not leave the tube and get reacted outside of the tube? Or even just react after the potato has left the gun.

Destin, I think your ignition point hypothesis is still correct. When you ignite from the end, an equal or greater volume of unburned fuel air mixture is getting pushed out of the barrel. Ignition from the center allows the maximum amount of flame propagation, which translates to the most complete burn as indicated by the flame front almost catching the potato. A check of muzzle energy would probably show an advantage for center ignition. With rear ignition, as the potato velocity approaches it's maximum, the pressure difference between the breech and barrel creates a forward flow of gasses to give the appearance that the flame front has stopped advancing. The secondary ignition is probably related to the change in burn rate in response to pressure for your choice of fuel air mixture.

Hey Destin, looks like you are using the classic hairspray for fuel.  As a student of the potato gun world, I find a can of starter fluid to work much better.  A half second spritz onto the inside wall of the combustion chamber is all it takes, and it burns very clean, leaving no sticky residue the way hairspray does.  You won't have to rasp the electrodes clean anymore.  Starter fluid is just ether and won't be too strong for your setup.

What you need is a plastic burst disk membrane between the combustion chamber and the potato. It allows for more pressure to build before actually propelling the potato. The propellant gasses won't escape before they're done combusting and you get the biggest bang for your buck. My buddy and I tested it with some polyethylene from some milk jugs and got almost a 25 percent increase in fps. It's the (roughly) same idea used in light-gas guns that can propel objects to over 7 KILOMETERS A SECOND.

Looking at the footage, would it be better to offset the ignition of the fuel 1/3 way down from the end? I am curious if that would allow better combustion with the remaining air and produce a farther distance in the projectile.

I wouldn't be surprised if the centre ignition created a higher muzzle velocity. The deflagration is moving in two fronts instead of one, meaning you have double the burn rate and therefore are creating a higher pressure. I don't think the unburned fuel would matter too much since the projectile has already left the barrel before combustion was complete in any case, so it already isn't making full use of the chemical energy available. You're just getting a backdraft in the chamber instead of a large muzzle flash. You'd need a chronograph to test it though.

Interestingly, a similar experiment has been done with actual firearms, with some blackpowder rifles using a front ignition, most famously the Dreyse needle gun and the Chassepot rifle. Burning from front to rear compressed the powder allowing for a faster and more complete burn, as well as producing less fouling as unburned powder wasn't thrown forwards down the barrel as with a conventional rear ignition. These aren't effects I'd expect to see in a gaseous fuel like a potato gun though, so it might not make any difference in this, although you might get a cool repetitive expansion and rarefaction effect similar to a pulse jet with the right air/fuel mix

I have few thoughts after seeing this.
1) Use pre-decompressed gas so you can control amount of fuel / stoichiometry of the reaction
2) You can try multi-gap spark ignition using few nails and just two connected electrodes like that:
---> --- --- --- <---
which will ignite mixture in few places simultaneously. Note that nails in between just need to be held in place, not connected to anything. A 6-wire configuration would give you enough degrees of freedom.
3) If you attempt this, don't be in proximity of that potato gun while firing.
Speed of pressure ramp-up might increase dramatically and polymers give nonlinear responses to basically any physical parameter change. I've done research on such polymers for a few years and don't trust them ;)

It's less about flow rate as it is opposed expansion. Like hitting your hand with a hammer while having it on a board vs hitting you hand with a hammer in the air. When you light in the middle, the air has to expand both ways, one way expands (and compresses the unlit fuel) towards the potato , the other expands (and compresses the unlit fuel) against the back of the gun, basically dividing the movement because once the unlit fuel decompresses and mixes and mixes oxygen it ignites and again compresses the unused fuel and repeats the process. That's why it looks like a yo-yo of flame. Ideally, the location of the ignitor should be just forward enough that the mix ignites fully without causing backwards compression on the unspent fuel, about 9/10's the radius of the chamber if you have the back flat, or the radius if you have a rounded back, similar to a touch hole on a cannon.

I don't think the 'running out of oxygen' hypothesis explains the effect. You can see a similar effect occur in the rear ignited shots when the flame front approaches the barrel before the potato starts to move.

The initial movement of the flame front is caused by two things, the propagation of the chemical reaction and the thermal expansion of the heated gas. As the deflagrating gas expands it will compress the remaining unignited gas in the tube. At some point the pressure of the unignited gas will reach the pressure of the ignited gas and thus the only way for the flame front to move now is by propagation of the chemical reaction, which appears as an apparent stopping of the flame front. At the other end of the tube, the potato starts to move down the barrel, allowing the ignited gas to keep expanding. The potato does move slower than the initial speed of the gas, which is why the flame front still appears to slow down. Once the potato leaves the barrel the pressure starts to drop inside the chamber, which allows the gas to start expanding again. Finally, the air will rush in at the end because, as stated by other commenters, the momentum of the expanding gas will carry more out of the cannon causing pressure inside the tube to drop below atmospheric pressure.

Destin! great video! I have a few tips and an idea for another fun experiment for you. 1) use less fuel. That combustion chamber is huge, but my gut tells me 3 seconds of fuel spray might be too much. 2) cut your potatoes in half so they look more like bullets. This doubles your ammo while providing a flat surface at the rear for the expanding gas to push on.
For an experiment, I tried building potato cannons with conical combustion chambers in high school. I'd love to see this replicated: three cannons with the same volume chamber, but one with the barrel coming out the wide end of the cone, one with the barrel out the narrow end, and one with a cylindrical chamber. All ignition is done at the back end. I think you'll be surprised at what happens! (hint: the chamber is very, very good at shaping the explosion. I had almost an order of magnitude between the distances achieved between the two conical chambers.)

Notice the end cap ignition - during the initial ignition, you see the flame front 'rebound' from the front of the combustion chamber. There's a pressure wave that forces the flame front back. I suspect this is much like the pressure wave in two-stroke engine systems with tuned pipes. It would be very interesting to experiment with different ignition points throughout the chamber. I suspect that for a given air/fuel mixture/chamber size, there might be a tuned length for the most efficient ignition point.

Is there a better location for the igniter that could give you the best of both worlds? It seems obvious to me that you get faster expansion with the center combustion, per your original hypothesis, but you just use less of the available fuel for propulsion. Could you move the igniter toward the rear enough to negate/reduce that pocket of unburnt fuel, reducing the waste but keeping the majority of the pressure increase?

Instead of assuming your hypothesis about starting a spark in the middle is wrong, consider the volume ratio of the chamber to the barrel. There's a balance between wasting fuel with a short barrel (fuel mixture problems aside) and having your combustion pressure collapse and slow the projectile.
I've seen some really cool projects using metered propane and multiple ignition points to achieve better efficiency (like how a hemi engine uses two spark plugs per cylinder). On top of that I've seen people use a membrane to seal off the barrel so they can add more air pressure to the chamber (like a turbocharger on a car) to add more fuel without messing up the air:fuel ratio, which then ruptures at combustion pressures. I would love to see more experiments with this potato gun.

Watching this video made me curious ... the main chamber ramps up a significant pressure, but the pressure begins to dissipate before the potato has traveled the length of the tube. I'm wondering if you'd get more exit velocity by sealing the forward 1/4 of the chamber and using a stack of valves (multiple valves in parallel) to transfer the pressure from the back of the chamber to the front of it, and then hold the high pressure at the front / inside the barrel while the hot gasses collapsed after cooling. Of course, the valves themselves reduce the cross-sectional area, and that increase in resistance will have /some/ effect in reducing the maximum pressure in the barrel. It might be the case that you just can't get enough valves in parallel for the increase in barrel pressure duration to out-weigh the reduced peak barrel pressure ... but, like I said, the video made me curious. Kudos on coming up with this idea for a high speed camera video!

Not trying to take anything away from previous knowledge you have shared with us on this channel. However in this video I feel that you are misleading your audience by calling this an explosion. what you have in your hands is a controlled burn. The combustion chamber in the potato gun works much like in an internal combustion engine. A spark is generated and ignites the fuel air mixture. As the mixture ignites there is a flame front that continues to burn from the source of ignition to the remainder of the cylinder. (also it's called a combustion engine and not an explosion engine) the only main difference here is that your cylinder is only going to build pressure until the pressure builds up enough to push the potato out of the barrel. Aside from all of that I really feel that running ads on your video as well as a sponsor (Audible) and having patreon supporters is getting too greedy for filming a transparent potato gun in slow motion. although I understand high speed cameras do cost quite a lot of money, however you've been using one for most of your videos so either you've purchased one quite a while ago or you go the much cheaper route and rent. Either way the more than six thousand dollars you pull in patreon support per video should be more than enough to cover the cost of renting a high speed camera and the cost of materials.

Now, the fun begins. Fit an Exhaust Gas Oxygen sensor in the end of the barrel and use a fuel injector to squirt your fuel in. Hook an arduino on to handle the ignition and injection and to monitor the gas, then you could have a feedback loop so that you could always have just about the perfect amount of fuel in your chamber.

Of course, more sensors would improve 'first firing guess' at the mix. Air pressure, temp, etc. And if you are going to automate the fuel injection, well, you could go the whole hog and get some N2O or O2 and another injector...

The flame that came out expanded to what is probably it's greatest pressure against the atmosphere, and then I think that since it reached that point and also needed more combustion to continue that pressure, it came back onto itself, thus creating a mushroom shape very quickly once the fuel for it's combustion was exhausted. If the fuel air mixture is not burned entirely from the layer around the edge of the chamber due to side wall cooling, and that is what causes the pollution and waste in combustion engines. Mini Backstory: I have a electronic technologist education and have been researching, with my limited knowledge for years, ways to produce and use renewable energy. The biggest obstacle I see is the energy density for Batteries/Capacitors/Super Capacitors, compared to fuel. Which is why I don't think we can ever entirely get away from burning fuel as an energy source. I think we can minimize our dependency to very sustainable levels, but there will always be a need in some applications.

Interesting hypothesis, but the most important measure of which ignition strategy is "better" is the muzzle velocity of the potato.  We ought to be able extract this from the video.  As a rough comparison, I determined that the first potato took 4.2 ms to traverse the final half of the barrel, and the second took 10.65 ms.  This comparison may not be valid if they were significantly different mass, but it would seem that lighting on the end is indeed "better".

I read an interesting article a while back about the efficiency of homogeneous mixtures versus heterogeneous mixtures in diesel cylinders.  The author initially guessed that a homogeneous mixture of fuel and air would provide a better burn for increased power and efficiency.  In his research, he discovered that he was quite wrong, and that the extended burn generated by the heterogeneous mixture provided considerably more power over the length of the cylinder stroke.  Watching the two burns in this video reminds me of the results he was getting.  The pressure in the rear-ignition firing seems very linear.  I'd be curious to see what the difference in velocities is.

Of course this combustion speed could also be dependent on how much fuel mixture there is in the barrel and the size of the potato.

Considering your findings thus far.... and thinking about it for ½ a sec. a couple additional questions and plausible efficiency increase come to mind.

Firstly. the questions.
Given the two firing methods. Is there a difference in the psi output between them?

If none or a nominal difference.

What is psi output at using a 3 second load of fuel?... 2 second? 1 second?

Hypothesis is there would eventually be seen a greater difference in psi output between the two firing methods as fuel input measured by seconds goes down.

There should bee a point where the center firing method becomes more efficient, requiring less fuel for the same or close to the same psi output. possibly even greater psi output.

Just a thought/hypothesis mind you... but one that would be interesting to see since you're pretty much set up to find out the answer.

Ok so this probably is silly but what happens when you ignite:
- "in the front" (so on the end of the chamber closest to the potato)
- in multiple spots at the same time (back/center, back/front, front/center, back/front/center)
- in an oxygen-enriched environment (for the extra danger)
- after preheating the walls (to presumably make the combustion more efficient - this will take a lot of modification to work though)
- if you add turbulences to mix the air (is there a small electric fan you could use in the chamber, which would survive the combustion? - this might act similarly to preheating, making combustion more efficient.)
